data.title: The Non-UPF Program Combats Ultra-Processed Foods (UPF) and Promotes Healthier Food Choices
data.description:
The Non-UPF Program Combats Ultra-Processed Foods (UPF) and Promotes Healthier Food Choices

The Non-UPF Program Combats Ultra-Processed Foods (UPF) and Promotes Healthier Food Choices

PR Newswire

PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 30, 2025

PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 30, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- The Non-UPF Program is a pioneering nonprofit dedicated to reducing ultra-processed foods (UPF) in American diets and replacing them with healthier foods. Trademarked in June 2024 and launched in December 2024, the Non-UPF Program provides the first U.S. certification for non-ultra-processed foods and is now proud to extend its comprehensive certification to the entire food industry.

 "Our goal is to cut through food label confusion and guide Americans toward choosing less processed foods."

Research shows that UPF are strongly associated with a higher risk of poor health and chronic diseases, including obesity, heart disease, type 2 diabetes, certain cancers, gastrointestinal disorders, and depression. Diet-related diseases already add about $50 billion annually to U.S. healthcare costs (NHLBI), and UPF further contribute to this growing financial burden.

Many national health experts and nutrition scientists have called for addressing UPF in the U.S. Dietary Guidelines. Our program steps in where government policy has yet to act, helping consumers easily identify and choose minimally processed, nutrient-rich foods.

UPF are industrialized formulations made from food derivatives and chemical additives, designed to be edible, convenient, and shelf-stable. They include ingredients not commonly found in a home kitchen (e.g., artificial flavors, colors, sweeteners, modified starches, high-fructose corn syrup) and are often high in sugar, salt, and unhealthy fats. These foods often undergo multiple industrial steps, such as extrusion, molding, or prefrying, to achieve a uniform texture and flavor. Scientists use the Nova Classification System to categorize foods by their level of processing:

  • Nova Group 4: Ultra-processed foods.
  • Nova Groups 1-3: Unprocessed/minimally processed, processed culinary ingredients, and processed foods.

"Our goal is to help Americans cut through the confusion in food labeling and provide clear guidance for less processed foods," said Melissa Halas, founder of the Non-UPF Program and a nationally recognized dietitian and nutrition expert. "By creating a reliable certification mark, consumers can shop with confidence and support brands committed to reducing UPF in the marketplace. There is a lack of government oversight and transparency in the food we eat, and many additives have not been adequately tested for safety."

Key Program Goals:

  • Certification for Transparency: Certifies food products 'Non-UPF' that meet criteria based on the Nova framework, to indicate that they are free from excessive processing, artificial additives, and harmful ingredients. Additional incentives support minimally processed foods like produce, whole grains, legumes, nuts, and seeds.
  • Educational Outreach: Provides webinars, workshops, and educational tools for consumers and healthcare practitioners, helping to identify UPF, understand health impact, and adopt easy, tasty, and practical ways to reduce them.
  • Collaboration with Researchers: Offers a digital platform connecting healthcare practitioners, registered dietitian nutritionists, nutrition scientists, innovators, responsible food industry leaders, and environmental experts to advance UPF research and promote a health-focused food system.
    • The Non-UPF Program is also conducting a study in collaboration with Teachers College, Columbia University (TCCU), and the Consumer Federation of America to assess dietitians' attitudes, beliefs, and knowledge regarding UPFs. (TCCU IRB# 26-034)

Our Team     
The Non-UPF Program is supported by an accomplished team of healthcare professionals, researchers, and leaders serving on its Board of Directors, Scientific Advisory Team, Advisory Board, Officers, and Partners.

Join the Movement
The Non-UPF Program invites food companies, health professionals, and consumers to join the movement toward healthier eating. Whether you're a brand seeking certification or an individual eager to reduce UPF, we offer tools and resources to help you take the next step toward a minimally processed, nutrient-rich diet.

For more information, visit www.nonupfprogram.org or contact team@nonupfprogram.org. Together, we can create a future where nutritious, minimally processed foods are accessible to all.

Contact: Melissa Halas, MA, RDN, CDCES Founder
Email: [team@nonupfprogram.org]
Website: www.nonupfprogram.org

View original content to download multimedia:https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-non-upf-program-combats-ultra-processed-foods-upf-and-promotes-healthier-food-choices-302599161.html

SOURCE The Non-UPF Program

data.title: Meta's stock slides toward its worst day in years as Wall Street pans 'runaway' AI spending
data.description:
By Britney Nguyen

Meta's spending is hard to rationalize, some analysts say, as it's uncertain whether heavy investments in AI will generate compelling returns

Meta's stock was down more than 11% as of 10 a.m. Thursday.

Meta Platforms Inc. just raised the midpoint of its capital-spending forecast for the third time this year, and that has some analysts spooked.

It's not just that Meta (META) is spending more on artificial intelligence, but that it's also unclear whether the types of AI investments that Facebook's parent company is pursuing so aggressively will yield appropriate financial returns. At least, that was the view of two analysts who downgraded the stock in the wake of Wednesday's results and earnings call.

Meta's stock was sliding more than 11% in morning trading Thursday, with some analysts drawing parallels to past plans for a spending spree that weren't received well by Wall Street. The stock is heading for its worst one-day drop since it plunged about 25% on Oct. 27, 2022 - also in the wake of spending concerns.

"Significant investment in Superintelligence despite unknown revenue opportunity mirrors 2021/2022 metaverse spending," Oppenheimer analysts said, referring to Meta's recently formed Superintelligence Labs focused on AI that would surpass human knowledge. After Wall Street panned earlier metaverse-spending plans, Meta went through a "year of efficiency" focused on cost cuts.

Meta is back to talking up big spending, and there's still "uncertainty" around the company's investments into AI, the Oppenheimer team said in a Wednesday note, while downgrading Meta's stock to perform from outperform. With Meta's after-hours stock drop, its price accurately reflected the company's new risk-reward balance, the analysts said.

The tech giant narrowed its expectations for capital expenditures to between $70 billion and $72 billion for this year, which would be well above the $39 billion that Meta spent last year. The company added that capex dollar growth will likely be "noticeably larger" next year, mostly due to continued spending on its AI-infrastructure build-out.

Read: Meta takes a $16 billion tax hit and earnings miss by wide margin

Meta's implied capex and operating expenditures for the fourth quarter are both 7% higher than the Wall Street consensus, Oppenheimer said. And the company's expectations for expenses to grow "significantly faster" in 2026, along with its view for capex dollar growth, puts Meta's numbers ahead of those of Wall Street, the analysts added.

In Oppenheimer's view, "investors will struggle to rationalize" Meta's price-to-earnings ratio "until there is visibility into 2027, as aggressive revenue growth [has been] offset by high spending." The analysts contrasted Meta's situation with that of Alphabet Inc. (GOOGL) (GOOG), which they said had "predictable earnings at a reasonable P/E." Meta and Alphabet shares are both trading at about 21 times 2027 earnings estimates, but Google's search business "could outgrow Meta at some point" next year, they said.

See more: Alphabet earnings are out. Here are the numbers driving the stock higher.

Benchmark analysts also downgraded Meta's stock on Thursday, moving to a hold rating from a buy rating. The analysts said that they expect Meta shares to be "rangebound at best until a sensible return case can be made for thus far runaway capex."

Despite the dominance of Meta's advertising business, the company "will need to justify returns" beyond that segment, the analysts said.

The Benchmark analysts said Meta's AI investments in other business areas, such as robotics and its Llama AI foundation models, "are less certain against fresh, comparably capitalized competition," from companies such as OpenAI, Google and Tesla Inc. (TSLA), as well as frontier AI labs.

Meta's stock was also likely reacting to a one-time income-tax charge that drove a large gap between what the company delivered on profit and what analysts were expecting. With the charge, Meta reported earnings per share of $1.05, compared with the $6.72 consensus on FactSet. Without the charge, Meta said its EPS would have been $7.25.

-Britney Nguyen

This content was created by MarketWatch, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. MarketWatch is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal. 




  (END) Dow Jones Newswires



  10-30-25 1017ET


Copyright (c) 2025 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

data.title: CORRECTING and REPLACING NETSCOUT Expands Capabilities to Support Enterprise Compliance Requirements in Cloud Environments
data.description:
NETSCOUT Extends Visibility Into Kubernetes Containers With Continuous Observability Innovation

Helps Organizations Understand the Why Behind Issues Across Private and Public Cloud Environments

NETSCOUT® SYSTEMS, INC. (NASDAQ: NTCT), a leading provider in observability, AIOps, cybersecurity, and DDoS attack protection solutions, today announced an innovation aimed at meeting organizations’ increasing needs for comprehensive observability within complex cloud environments. With the ever-growing demands of large, multi-cluster Kubernetes deployments, organizations often face significant challenges related to visibility and blind spots in their environments.

Omnis® KlearSight Sensor for Kubernetes (KlearSight) delivers deep, actionable, and real-time insights into system performance, health, and cost drivers. This solution is specifically designed to support dynamic and distributed architectures, environments that are challenging to monitor due to their encrypted nature. KlearSight captures Kubernetes packets and SSL messages directly from the Linux kernel’s networking stack after decryption has occurred. It then converts this data into standard IT traffic, enabling visibility into application-layer communications without requiring access to encryption keys. By providing robust visibility into these cloud environments, KlearSight empowers organizations to better manage and optimize their infrastructure, ensuring more reliable and efficient operations.

“Microservices running on a Kubernetes cluster generate multiple metrics, events, logs, and traces to provide some visibility across complex multi-cloud environments,” stated Jim Frey, principal analyst, Omdia. “However, searching through telemetry data streams to determine the root cause of an incident can be like searching for multiple needles across multiple haystacks. The ultimate source of truth lies in packets, and organizations can only benefit by establishing this level of visibility enterprise-wide, including the cloud and Kubernetes environments. Time and again, this has proven to be crucial for rapid recognition and diagnosis of performance incidents and issues while also enhancing AI-driven observability.”

Developed from NETSCOUT’s expertise in network traffic analysis, deep packet inspection (DPI), and real-time traffic intelligence, KlearSight uses extended Berkeley Packet Filter (eBPF) technology to extract packets from within the Linux kernel’s networking stack. It extends and enhances observability to understand system behavior and accelerate troubleshooting and incident response with unprecedented, low-overhead access to granular system and application data. The result is moving beyond monitoring what is happening in the environment towards understanding the why of any issue, including unusual patterns and anomalies, that often go unnoticed.

“NETSCOUT has been delivering innovative observability and visibility solutions that address end-through-end performance challenges for decades,” stated Phil Gray, AVP, product management, NETSCOUT. “Our solutions are mission-critical to large enterprises across all industries, especially as AI and cloud complexity continue to accelerate.”

NETSCOUT’s mission is to keep the connected world running by helping customers make smarter, better decisions – faster – to keep them resilient against disruptions of any kind. Our enterprise, service provider, and government agency customers have some of the most complex digital infrastructures in the world, and we partner with leading technology companies to drive customer success. Recently, NETSCOUT was recognized for network observability leadership in the QKS Group’s SPARK Matrix™: Network Observability, Q3 2025, and was also honored as the recipient of the CRN Tech Innovators award in the Application Performance / Observability category for overcoming remote office observability challenges with cost-effective nGenius Edge Sensors.

Visit our website to learn more about Omnis KlearSight Sensor for Kubernetes and our nGenius Enterprise Performance Management solution.

About NETSCOUT

NETSCOUT SYSTEMS, INC. (NASDAQ: NTCT) protects the connected world from cyberattacks and performance and availability disruptions through its unique visibility platform and solutions powered by its pioneering deep packet inspection at scale technology. NETSCOUT serves the world’s largest enterprises, service providers, and public sector organizations. Learn more at www.netscout.com or follow @NETSCOUT on LinkedIn, X, or Facebook.

©2025 NETSCOUT SYSTEMS, INC. All rights reserved. Third-party trademarks mentioned are the property of their respective owners.

Chris Lucas
NETSCOUT Systems, Inc.
+1 978 614 4124
chris.lucas@netscout.com

Chris Shattuck
Finn Partners for NETSCOUT
+1 404 502 6755
NETSCOUT-US@FinnPartners.com

data.title: Genestra Brands Kicks Off Its In My Gut Check Era Campaign to Champion Digestive Wellness
data.description:
Genestra Brands Kicks Off Its In My Gut Check Era Campaign to Champion Digestive Wellness

Why Canadians Are Missing Out on Key Gut Health Benefits

Digestive health challenges are increasingly prevalent in Canada, with more than 57 per cent of Canadians wanting to improve their gut health but not knowing how. Beyond digestion, gut health is the cornerstone of whole-body wellness. With so much misinformation and quick-fix health trends, many Canadians remain unsure how to select supplements that truly support their gut health. That’s why Genestra Brands, a leader in professional-grade probiotics, is launching its third annual PR campaign to continue its commitment to educating both consumers and the industry on common misconceptions and gaps in awareness.

This press release features multimedia. View the full release here: https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20251030213066/en/

Genestra Brands® HMF Probiotics available on Amazon.

“The microbiome interacts with almost every part of our physiology, it even drives the development of a competent immune system,” says Dr. Nigel Plummer, PhD. “Genestra’s HMF Probiotics support this essential community, helping people maintain gut health throughout life.”

Addresses a Growing Need for Gut Health Education

The National Public Relations Campaign, In My Gut Check Era is designed to help Canadians understand that supporting the microbiome is one of the most powerful steps we can take to influence overall health. Genestra’s science-backed gut health research links the microbiome to improve immunity, mood, skin, sleep, and energy, empowering Canadians to make informed decisions about their digestive wellness.

"What we’re learning from decades of research is that the microbiome is not a passive system, it’s actually constantly interacting with our physiology,” says Dr. Jacqueline van der Made, Naturopathic Doctor. “When the microbiome is disrupted, we may see ripple effects in areas as diverse as sleep, skin health, and mental well-being. By helping Canadians connect these dots, we can shift the conversation from ‘gut health is about digestion’ to ‘gut health is central to overall wellness.’”

Empowering Consumers Through Education

Genestra aims to replace this uncertainty with science-backed, reliable education, helping both consumers and healthcare practitioners navigate the complex world of digestive wellness.

One important tip for maximizing the benefits of probiotics is to take them with food. On an empty stomach, the pH is highly acidic around 2.8 to 3.2 which can be harsh for probiotic organisms. Consuming probiotics alongside a meal helps neutralize stomach acid to the ideal pH of 3.8 to 4.5, creating an optimal environment for these beneficial bacteria to thrive and support digestive health.

“Probiotics are the only living type of supplement, and because they are living, they’re in a sort of limbo suspended animation because we freeze dry them,” says Dr. Plummer. “When you take a probiotic and they reach your stomach and the intestinal tracts, these freeze dried organisms come into contact with water and start to activate again.”

HMF Probiotic Line

Genestra’s HMF Probiotics are designed to protect the microbiome and make gut health accessible at every stage of life. From the last 35 years of research Genestra has conducted 35 published randomized, placebo-controlled trials which have shown that the HMF consortia of probiotic strains produces the widest range of health benefits of any multi-strain probiotic globally.

“The strength of the HMF line lies in its precision with each probiotic strain carefully identified and supported by clinical research, not just assumed to work because of its species,” said Dr. van der Made. “HMF has built one of the most robust scientific foundations in the probiotic field, and for practitioners that means we’re not guessing, we’re choosing products with documented efficacy, safety, and reliability.”

Genestra Brands HMF Probiotics, made of Human MicroFlora, offers over thirty different probiotics ensuring there is a solution for everyone. Genestra Brands advises consulting a healthcare practitioner to ensure you choose the product best suited to your individual needs. You can purchase the HMF line on Amazon.ca. Always read and follow the label to ensure proper use.

For the first time ever, in year three of Genestra’s annual educational campaign, it is introducing a short brand video to tell the story of its origins and reinforce its leadership in the industry. Watch the brand video on YouTube.

About Genestra Brands® (https://www.genestra.ca/en):

For over 30 years Genestra Brands® has supported individualized treatment plans with 350+ professional-grade products in a variety of formats, proven safe, effective, and reliable.

Genestra values the importance of well-sourced ingredients and careful formulation, consciously ensuring their products are backed by clinical or traditional evidence. They care about their customers and believe in the production of targeted products that make a positive difference in the health of those who choose them. Genestra Brands® is headquartered in Richmond Hill, ON, Canada. For additional information, please visit https://www.genestra.ca/en.

For more information, please contact:

Marissa Themeles, Account Manager
Elevator PR
marissa@elevatorinc.com
416-258-7595

data.title: My boss made us sign new contracts to return to the office. Should we fight back?
data.description:
By Quentin Fottrell

'There are several team members with very long commutes'

"Before people say snarky things like, 'Just suck it up and go into the office,' we were all hired as hybrid employees." (Photo subject is a model.)

Dear Quentin,

My question relates to paid time off and benefits. We have had a policy at work since the end of the pandemic that we are expected to be in the office four out of five days a week. Most people work from home on Fridays. The company has just enacted a new rule where, if you take a vacation day, you are expected to come to the office the other four days.

Many people on my team feel this is punishment for taking time off. If you are taking paid time off, it should be your day to use as if it were an office day. Before people say snarky things like, "Just suck it up and go into the office," we were all hired as hybrid employees, initially only working two days in the office with three days working from home.

Last year, our employer made us sign new contracts with revised office hours, moving to the new four-day-in-office policy. Several team members have very long commutes, and this makes a big difference to them. There's talk of a mutiny. Do you think it's ethical for our management to use paid time off to get people back to the office?

Disgruntled Employee

Related: 'I fear a significant decline in the S&P 500': I'm 78. Do I sell my tech stocks before it's too late?

Changing existing contracts can be tricky for both parties, especially under employment-at-will laws, where an employer may terminate your employment at any time.

Dear Disgruntled,

Pick your battles - and the timing of those battles.

Yours is a legal question more than an ethical one. It all depends on the nature of your existing contracts, what is (or is not) specified, and employment law in your state. There is no straightforward answer. From a human-resources perspective, it makes little sense to effectively conflate vacation days with work-from-home days, and it also seems to run counter to promoting goodwill. Paid time off is part of your contract and should be treated as such.

A happy employee is a productive employee. A disgruntled employee will be more likely to sow discontent.

Nickel-and-diming employees' remote-working days makes less sense for your management from a productivity point of view. A happy employee is a productive employee. An unhappy and disgruntled employee will be more likely to complain, grumble, debate, gossip and sow discontent among other employees. An unhappy employee is more likely to engage in contrarian or insubordinate behavior and will generally create a nuisance. It can bring down the entire team and affect company morale.

Changing existing contracts can be tricky for both parties, especially under employment-at-will laws, where a company may terminate your employment at any time, for any reason and without any legal ramifications. In the U.S., 49 out of 50 states, plus the District of Columbia, follow employment-at-will laws by default - with the exception being Montana, where employers need "good cause" to terminate an employee after their probationary period has ended.

Don't miss: 'I feel slighted': My late husband's parents left me nothing in their will. Is that thoughtless?

An uncertain time

The U.S. labor market is going through an uncertain time. Before the government shutdown began on Oct. 1, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said the U.S. unemployment rate had risen to 4.3% in August from 4.2% the prior month. On Monday, the Chicago Federal Reserve, using a mixture of private-sector data including job boards, polls and data from payroll firms, estimated that the unemployment rate has held steady in October at around 4.3%. Still, that's only an estimate of what's happening out there.

The government has not released its September jobs report due to the prolonged government shutdown, but most economists estimate that new unemployment filings reached roughly 220,000 in mid-October, leaving them effectively unchanged since the shutdown began. On Tuesday, payroll firm ADP said private-sector employers added an average of 14,250 jobs per week in the four weeks ending Oct. 11.

Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's, said the lack of data adds to the uncertainty surrounding the labor market. Writing on X earlier this month, he said, "There is no more important economic data, particularly now, when the job market is sputtering and the Federal Reserve is a few weeks from another meeting when it must decide whether to continue cutting interest rates." He added that "not having the BLS jobs data is a serious problem for assessing the health of the economy and making good policy decisions."

Legal complexities

The Vigilante Law Firm, which has offices in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, says if your employer creates a new employment agreement that changes the roles and responsibilities that fall under your given job title, there could be legal consequences. "They must receive your explicit, willing consent to these changes, otherwise this legally-binding contract may be deemed invalid and ineffective," it says.

"Your New Jersey-based employer is allowed to bring forward a new employment agreement even after you have already started working for them," the law firm says. "However, it is illegal for them to 'force' you to sign this agreement through duress or undue influence. So, your employer cannot change the terms of your employment without informing you first; this may be considered a unilateral change that results in a breach of contract."

If you win, it may turn out to be a pyrrhic victory.

But if you win, it may turn out to be a pyrrhic victory. "While you have the right to refuse your signature, your employer equally has the right to fire you over your unwillingness to comply with their new terms and conditions," the law firm adds. "Further, if you get fired over a refusal to sign, you may even become disqualified from receiving the government's unemployment benefits program, among other consequences."

The Civil Rights Act sets out several protected classes: race; color; religion; sex, including pregnancy, sexual orientation and gender identity; and national origin. Other laws protect workers against discrimination based on age (for employees who are 40 or older); disability, and genetic information, including family medical history, according to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Political speech or political affiliation is not protected.

Don't miss: My husband and I have $7K in Social Security and $2.5 million in stocks. What could go wrong?

Magnitude of the changes

However, Geonetta & Frucht, a law firm based in Oakland, Calif., says employees may have more leverage than they think when they're presented with a new contract, even though they're still working under an existing contract. "Contract modifications require both your consent and that of your employer," it says. "Therefore, any changes made without you agreeing to them are null and void."

The law firm adds: "Depending on the magnitude of changes made, the court might nullify the employment contract entirely. An employer that amends a contract without your consent has no right to enforce the amended contract terms. In some instances, you can take the employer to court for breach of the original contract and recover damages. Serious legal consequences await any party that changes the terms without the other party's consent."

Sometimes it's easier to change your place of employment than to change the company itself. In this job market, however, there are no guarantees. Don't leap before you have your next role signed, sealed and delivered. Every company has its own culture, priorities and rules, and those can change as management changes. Before you stage a mutiny, think about the damage you could inflict upon yourself.

Related: 'They will drown you too': My coworker found out I inherited money - and harassed me to give him a loan

You can email The Moneyist with any financial and ethical questions at qfottrell@marketwatch.com, and follow Quentin Fottrell on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter.

The Moneyist regrets he cannot reply to questions individually.

Previous columns by Quentin Fottrell:

'I'll retire when I'm dead': My 401(k) lost $50,000 in the market turmoil. I'm in my early 40s. What should I do now?

'I'm absolutely terrible at managing money': I'm 35 with zero savings and $8,000 debt. How do I turn my life around?

'This woman destroyed my heart and soul': After my wife died, her mother turned on me - and presented me with a secret will

Check out the Moneyist private Facebook group, where members help answer life's thorniest money issues. Post your questions, or weigh in on the latest Moneyist columns.

-Quentin Fottrell

This content was created by MarketWatch, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. MarketWatch is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal. 




  (END) Dow Jones Newswires



  10-30-25 1000ET


Copyright (c) 2025 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

data.title: Even if baby boomers don't break Social Security, millennials and Gen Z will be in trouble. Here's why.
data.description:
By Alessandra Malito

Major Social Security reform could change the way the program serves young Americans in the future.

They entered the job market during the Great Recession and began to make strides in their careers as a global pandemic hit, so perhaps it's no surprise that millennials may wind up historically unlucky when it comes to Social Security.

Right now, their wages are helping to support the retirement of one of the largest generations in history, the baby boomers, who are hoovering up benefits amid concerns about the future of the Social Security program's finances. But if demographic trends continue as expected, there won't be enough workers to finance the retirement security of millennials, who are also part of an unusually large generation.

"In some ways, the millennials are on both sides of it," said Gopi Shah Goda, director of the Retirement Security Project at the Brookings Institution. "They're paying into the program at a moment where baby boomers are retiring and collecting benefits - but with the next generation or two generations, there might be fewer of them to pay their benefits."

Already, the Social Security program is running out of money. Trustees warn the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance trust fund, which pays out retiree and survivor benefits, could become insolvent as early as 2033 - in which case recipients across the board would receive about 77% of the benefits they were expecting.

Given that baby boomers are an unusually large generation, some younger Americans have wondered if they'll "break Social Security," while others have questioned if the boomer generation dying off will make the program easier to fund.

But unfortunately for millennials and the generations that follow, that isn't how it works.

"This is bigger than just the baby boomers retiring," Brookings's Goda said.

Part of the problem lies in how many workers there are compared to beneficiaries, known as the worker-to-beneficiary ratio.

There are two sides to the ratio: the workers who pay into the system, and the beneficiaries who receive benefits from it. As baby boomers move away from the workforce and into retirement, the number of beneficiaries increases. But there is also a decline in fertility rates, producing fewer workers who pay into the system.

See: The man who fixed Social Security when it went broke in the '80s has some advice for today's politicians

There were just 2.7 workers per beneficiary in 2023, according to a recent Pew Research Center report, and that ratio is expected to decline to 2.1 by the end of the century. Comparatively, the ratio was 3.2 in 1975, according to the Social Security Administration.

The SSA's trust fund for Old-Age and Survivors Insurance, which is expected to be depleted first, is already paying out more than it is bringing in; in 2024, its costs exceeded its income by $103.2 billion, according to the trustees report. The Disability Insurance trust fund - which pays monthly benefits to eligible disabled workers and their spouses and children - is expected to stay solvent until at least 2099, bringing the difference between the program's total costs and income to $67 billion.

Shifts in U.S. demographics

Actuaries account for fertility and longevity rates when they make their estimates about Social Security's solvency, experts noted.

"The underlying demographic patterns that have led to the aging of the U.S. population have long been reflected in Social Security's financial projections, consistently showing financial challenges that extend well into the future," Sam Gutterman, chair of the American Academy of Actuaries' Social Security Committee, said in a statement. "If Congress does not act in a timely manner, [Social Security's] financial shortfall will endure long after the baby boomers stop receiving benefits."

In addition to declining birth rates among the native-born U.S. population, the impact of changing immigration policy is also complicating Social Security's future, experts said.

There has been controversy and confusion around Social Security and immigration, but unauthorized immigrants - who may pay into the system through payroll taxes - do not receive benefits. Only "lawfully present noncitizens of the United States who meet all eligibility requirements can qualify for Social Security benefits," according to the SSA, while immigrants without this legal status do not.

A decline in immigration into the U.S. would hurt the program's finances, according to experts. Immigrants, even those who aren't in the U.S. legally, can contribute to Social Security in two ways: financially, through payroll taxes, and demographically, by having children who will later become workers that pay into the system.

"With a lower fertility rate, we have fewer workers contributing to the system, driving down the worker-to-beneficiary ratio," said Kathleen Romig, director of Social Security and disability policy at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. The problem is "compounded by immigration rates plummeting," she added.

The country's foreign-born population decreased by more than 1 million people between January and June 2025, the first such decline since the 1960s, according to the Pew Research Center, while 19% of the country's labor force were immigrants, down from 20% in January. Recent immigration-policy changes, including during the Biden and Trump administrations, have led to the decline, Pew reported.

"Women are having fewer babies and the U.S. is welcoming dramatically less immigrants," Romig said. "It affects things longer term."

Where Social Security reform fits in

Given all of these demographic shifts, changes to the system are inevitable.

"I don't view these things as a crisis," said Eric Kingson, professor emeritus at Syracuse University's School of Social Work. "We are always going to have to make changes in complex and important systems like this. This is the nation's most popular and successful program."

Americans want to see change within the Social Security program, even if it costs them. Across generational, political and economic lines, individuals agree the program is worth saving, according to a National Academy of Social Insurance survey of more than 2,000 Americans. As part of the survey, the organization asked about a package of provisions that would boost the program's finances - such as by increasing the payroll-tax rate, or removing the income cap for how much workers must earn before they no longer have to pay into the system for the rest of the year.

Legislators have yet to decide on what to do about Social Security reform. In a Fox Business interview, SSA Commissioner Frank Bisignano said that the White House, Congress and the Social Security trustees would come together to find a solution. "And that's where the real work will happen. And that'll take a while, but we have plenty of time," he said on "Mornings with Maria." Bisignano later took to the social-media website X to clarify that he is "committed to protecting and preserving Social Security."

Read: Social Security's commissioner says younger generations may have a different set of rules. Should Gen Z even plan for it?

With depletion closing in, legislators have yet to decide on how to fix the program. Along with raising the income cap on workers who pay into the system or increasing the payroll tax, possible reform includes upping the full retirement age, which is when claimants are eligible for 100% of the benefit they're owed. The full retirement age currently is 67 for anyone born in and after 1960, and there have been suggestions publicly discussed to raise it for current younger workers.

There are other, more nuanced options that could also affect solvency. The American Academy of Actuaries has an interactive game called the Social Security Challenge, which allows users to see how various adjustments to the program would affect its financing status.

Millennials and younger generations are the ones most likely to be affected by any legislative alterations to the program, as it often takes years to implement changes even after they've become law. The 1983 amendments to Social Security included increasing the full retirement age from 65 to 67 - but that only took effect in 2000.

"What people don't fully realize is that current workers have as much or a bigger stake in how the program is reformed going forward than current retirees, because they're the ones who are paying the bills," Brookings's Goda said. "What the future of the program looks like has the biggest implication for current workers and less so for current retirees."

-Alessandra Malito

This content was created by MarketWatch, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. MarketWatch is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal. 




  (END) Dow Jones Newswires



  10-30-25 1000ET


Copyright (c) 2025 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

data.title: Hershey's Halloween sales have disappointed, but there's hope for last-minute buying
data.description:
By Steve Gelsi

Chocolate giant says seasonal sales started slower than expected, but overall Halloween participation should pick up to be in line with last year

Hershey said Halloween sales have been soft this year but last-minute buying is expected to bring the business up to 2024 levels.

Hershey Co. said Thursday that candy buying ahead of Halloween has been disappointing so far, as warmer weather and a Friday holiday have people waiting until the last minute to go shopping.

The company (HSY) said that the seasonal tradition remains important to consumers, and it expects purchasing to pick up, bringing sales in line with last year.

"While Hershey's Halloween performance has been disappointing, the softness is not broad-based across our business," said Chief Executive Kirk Tanner.

A strong launch of the Reese's Oreo product and a rebound in chocolate sales have prompted Hershey's to raise its outlook for full-year, year-over-year sales growth to about 3% from at least 2%. And so far this year, Hershey said its chocolate retail sales have returned to growth, they have increased 4% after a previous 1% decline in 2024.

Still, the stock dropped 3.8% in morning trading, toward the lowest prices seen since mid-July.

During the third quarter, Reese's Oreo was the "top new item" in the candy, mint and gum category, the company said, with retail-sales trends exceeding targets.

The Reese's Oreo

"Early data shows that Reese's Oreo overindexes with Gen Z and millennial buyers, a priority audience for the brand," Tanner said. The company is preparing fresh advertising and partnerships to raise the confectionery's profile on Instagram, TikTok and through live events.

Overall, net sales for the third quarter increased 6.5% from a year ago to $3.18 billion, ahead of the FactSet consensus revenue estimate of $3.12 billion.

While Hershey has managed to boost prices, and as tariff costs have declined, the extra revenue "only partially mitigates" inflation from higher cocoa costs, which are still about 70% above levels in 2023.

Hershey said it expects cocoa prices to come down over time, with a larger global supply surplus expected for the 2025 and 2026 crop thanthe prior season.

Third-quarter net income fell to $276.3 million from $446.3 million in the year-ago quarter, while adjusted earnings per share of $1.30 handily beat the FactSet consensus EPS estimate of $1.07.

The company raised its outlook for 2025 EPS to between $5.90 and $6 from a range of $5.81 to $6. That compares with the analyst EPS projection of $6.02 a share, and with the year-ago level of $9.37 a share.

The selloff in Hershey's stock has turned it negative for the year. It has now slipped 0.4% in 2025, while the S&P 500 index SPX has advanced 16.4%.

-Steve Gelsi

This content was created by MarketWatch, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. MarketWatch is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal. 




  (END) Dow Jones Newswires



  10-30-25 0945ET


Copyright (c) 2025 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

data.title: Flagship Healthcare Trust Now Available on iCapital Marketplace, Expanding Access to Healthcare Real Estate Investing
data.description:
Flagship Healthcare Trust Now Available on iCapital Marketplace, Expanding Access to Healthcare Real Estate Investing

Flagship Healthcare Trust Now Available on iCapital Marketplace, Expanding Access to Healthcare Real Estate Investing

PR Newswire

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 30, 2025

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 30, 2025/PRNewswire/ -- Flagship Healthcare Trust, Inc. (Flagship REIT), a Charlotte-based outpatient healthcare real estate investment trust, focused on medical outpatient buildings and ambulatory surgery centers, today announced that its offering is now available to registered investment advisors (RIAs), family offices, and their accredited investor clients through the iCapital Marketplace.

By joining iCapital Marketplace, Flagship brings institutional-quality outpatient healthcare real estate access to a broader network of wealth managers and their clients, providing exposure to one of the most resilient and in-demand sectors in private markets.

Through iCapital Marketplace, financial advisors can now access Flagship Healthcare Trust, gaining exposure to:

  • A diversified portfolio of medical outpatient buildings across more than 12 states in the Southeast and Southern Mid-Atlantic
  • Consistent income generation supported by long-term occupancy from leading healthcare providers and physician groups
  • Sector tailwinds driven by demographic trends, including an aging population, physician shortages, and rising demand for outpatient care
  • Resilience across economic cycles , underpinned by the essential nature of healthcare delivery

"Our mission is to deliver stable, long-term value through ownership of mission-critical outpatient healthcare real estate," said Brannen Edge, CEO of Flagship Healthcare Trust. "We've built a portfolio focused on the Southeast and Southern Mid-Atlantic — regions experiencing strong population growth and rising demand for outpatient care. Joining iCapital Marketplace enables us to make this strategy accessible to more qualified investors and advisors looking for consistent income, diversification, and long-term alignment in an essential sector."

This announcement follows a period of strong growth and momentum for the Flagship platform, including:

  • A geographically diverse footprint of 109 medical outpatient buildings concentrated strategically across the Southeast and Southern Mid-Atlantic
  • Continued expansion into high-growth secondary and tertiary markets, where population growth and healthcare demand are outpacing national averages
  • Strong tenant relationships and retention, supported by deep market expertise and local presence

Flagship Healthcare Trust's investment strategy seeks to deliver stable quarterly income, capital preservation, and long-term value creation. The Trust focuses on outpatient medical facilities that provide essential healthcare services — including primary care, diagnostics, and specialty treatments — which are critical to the broader continuum of care. As the healthcare system evolves to deliver more services in outpatient settings, driven by improved outcomes, cost efficiency, and patient convenience, these assets play an increasingly vital role in supporting both acute and chronic care delivery. This structural trend underscores the durability and growth potential of the outpatient healthcare real estate sector.

About Flagship Healthcare Trust
 Flagship Healthcare Trust, Inc. (Flagship REIT), is a private real estate investment trust that owns clinical healthcare assets throughout the United States and focused in the Southeast and Mid-Atlantic. Flagship REIT holds interest in 109 properties comprising 3.0 million square feet of space and valued at more than $1.1 billion. For further information, visit www.FlagshipHP.com/REIT .

About Flagship Healthcare Properties
 Flagship Healthcare Properties, LLC (Flagship) is an outpatient healthcare real estate firm serving clients throughout the United States. Headquartered in Charlotte, North Carolina, Flagship offers a full range of real estate services, including acquisitions, development, leasing and brokerage, as well as facilities, property and asset management. Flagship serves as the manager of its private REIT, Flagship Healthcare Trust, Inc. For further information, visit www.FlagshipHP.com .

This press release is for informational purposes only and does not constitute an offer to sell or a solicitation of an offer to buy any security. Investments in Flagship are offered only to eligible accredited investors through official offering documents, which should be reviewed carefully before investing.

MEDIA CONTACT: Taylor Mumma, 919.830.1580; taylor@rachelsutherland.net

View original content to download multimedia:https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/flagship-healthcare-trust-now-available-on-icapital-marketplace-expanding-access-to-healthcare-real-estate-investing-302598606.html

SOURCE Flagship Healthcare Trust, Inc.

data.title: Lunai Bioworks Harnesses AI and Zebrafish Data to Advance Early Detection of Neurotoxic Compounds
data.description:
NEW YORK, NY / ACCESS Newswire / October 30, 2025 / In the face of growing global concern over the potential use of chemical weapons such as the nerve agent Sarin, Lunai Bioworks Inc. (NASDAQ:LNAI) today announced promising early results from its AI-based platform designed to identify compounds that interact with acetylcholinesterase (AChE), the same molecular target affected by nerve agents.

"This research brings us closer to a future where proactive, AI-powered screening can detect and evaluate neurotoxic compounds before they become threats," said David Weinstein, CEO of Lunai Bioworks. "Our vision is to use in vivo systems like zebrafish, combined with predictive AI, to rapidly identify neurotoxic threats and screen for countermeasures, and leverage our AI models to help safeguard against the creation of new neurotoxins."

Using a combination of chemical feature analysis and machine learning classifiers, Lunai's platform demonstrated an ability to differentiate active AChE inhibitors from inactive compounds with high accuracy (0.94 AUROC; Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve). The work builds on models trained using the company's in-house neuroactive compound screening data, as well as public sources, and applies predictive modeling to identify chemical signatures associated with AChE inhibition. Compounds with previously unidentified, potential neurotoxic activity have been identified for follow-up and validation.

Lunai's work represents a responsible application of AI, focused on defense and public health, not harm. The announcement comes amid increasing concern about the potential misuse of generative AI technologies, underscored by a recent NBC News investigation showing how AI chatbots could be manipulated to share instructions for creating dangerous substances, including nerve agents.

In future phases, the company plans to integrate its behavioral zebrafish profiling platform to observe real-time physiological effects of predicted inhibitors, helping prioritize candidate compounds for further development as potential countermeasures.

Zebrafish are an FDA-recognized model for toxicology and drug discovery, offering a unique balance of genetic relevance to humans and scalability unmatched by rodent models. Lunai's platform leverages these advantages by coupling high-throughput behavioral assays in zebrafish with machine learning models trained to recognize neurotoxic phenotypes. This approach enables rapid, low-cost screening of both suspected threat agents and potential countermeasure compounds, often identifying hits within days rather than months, a critical advantage in time-sensitive defense and public health scenarios.

To support collaboration, Lunai has embedded its predictive model into a customized dashboard, allowing partners to explore their chemical structures and determine if they have potential neurotoxicity.

About Lunai

Lunai Bioworks Inc. is an AI-powered drug discovery and biodefense company pioneering safe and responsible generative biology. With proprietary neurotoxicity datasets, advanced machine learning, and a focus on dual-use risk management, Lunai is redefining how artificial intelligence can accelerate therapeutic innovation while safeguarding society from emerging threats.

Forward-Looking Statements:
